title: 109_s30
content: The Act may be cited as the "Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2006". The Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2006 emphasizes the importance of experienced counsel, protecting privileged communications, and enhancing compliance programs through clarity on attorney-client privilege. The Department of Justice and other agencies have increasingly used tactics that undermine the adversarial system of justice by encouraging organizations to waive attorney-client privilege and work product protections to avoid indictment. An indictment can have devastating consequences on an organization, potentially eliminating its ability to survive post-indictment or dispute the charges at trial. The purpose of the Act is to set clear limits on government agencies' tactics that encroach on employees' constitutional rights and legal protections. It aims to preserve attorney-client privilege and work product protections for organizations and employees, ensuring these rights are not used to conceal wrongdoing or evade the law. The Act aims to preserve attorney-client privilege and work product protections for organizations and employees in investigations and enforcement matters. It defines attorney-client privilege and attorney work product in the context of litigation. The Act aims to protect attorney-client privilege and work product in investigations. It prohibits agents or attorneys from demanding disclosure of protected communications or conditioning charging decisions on cooperation with the Government. The Act protects attorney-client privilege and work product in investigations by allowing organizations to provide legal counsel, contribute to defense fees, enter joint defense agreements, share information, and not sanction employees. The Act prohibits organizations from sanctioning employees for exercising constitutional rights in response to Government requests or demanding actions contrary to employee rights. It does not restrict agents or attorneys from seeking unprotected communication or prevent voluntary disclosures.
